author: The Australian
title: As-a-service deliveries to come automatically
text:
VIDEO: How Australian start-ups can achieve world domination
GRAPHIC: How does Australia compare with the rest of the world?
QUIZ: How much do you really know about startups?
The emerging outsourcing model of the future will require vendors to drive far greater automation into the services that they offer, according to a legal expert.
An “As-A-Service’’ economy was now unfolding beyond the current offerings of Infrastructure-As-A-Service, Platform-As-A-Service and Software-As-A-Service.
“What it’s about is buying a service that will deliver you a particular business operation in a much more automated way,’’ Gilbert+Tobin partner Bernadette Jew said. “It’s about combining the cloud, mobility, the Internet of Things, robotic process automation and data analytics.’’
Ms Jew has worked on mining giant Rio Tinto’s major cloud outsourcing As-A-Service deal with Accenture announced earlier this year.
“The next wave of saving is ­really going to come not through labour arbitrage but much more automation of these business processes,’’ she told The Australian. The new model would involve almost anything being converted into “As-A-Service’’, from back-office functions, IT operations, production processes, supply chain management and customer-facing operations.
“In many ways, the new kind of As-A-Service outsourcing is going to give enterprises a chance to leapfrog on to new technologies,’’ Ms Jew said.
The new As-A-Service outsourcing would involve entirely different commercial models.
“The As-A-Service model is simpler, focused on outcomes rather than vendor specifications, it’s pay-as-you-go, pay-by-the-drink; it’s almost coming to an outsourcing for the masses because you don’t have these large set-up costs,’’ she said.
Ms Jew warned that vendors had to deliver more sophisticated service offerings.
And she added that the As-A-Service models would move ahead quicker in industries such as insurance, financial services, HR and recruitment, and the health sector.
